author: HCAndersen
text: THERE was once a fine gentleman who possessed among other things a boot-jack and a hair-brush; but he had also the finest shirt-collar in the world, and of this collar we are about to hear a story.

author: HCAndersen
text: The collar had become so old that he began to think about getting married; and one day he happened to find himself in the same washing-tub as a garter.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Upon my word," said the shirt-collar, "I have never seen anything so slim and delicate, so neat and soft before.

author: HCAndersen
text: May I venture to ask your name?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I shall not tell you," replied the garter.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Where do you reside when you are at home?" asked the shirt-collar.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the garter was naturally shy, and did not know how to answer such a question.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I presume you are a girdle," said the shirt-collar, "a sort of under girdle.

author: HCAndersen
text: I see that you are useful, as well as ornamental, my little lady."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You must not speak to me," said the garter; "I do not think I have given you any encouragement to do so."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, when any one is as beautiful as you are," said the shirt-collar, "is not that encouragement enough?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Get away; don't come so near me," said the garter, "you appear to me quite like a man."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am a fine gentleman certainly," said the shirt-collar, "I possess a boot-jack and a hair-brush."

author: HCAndersen
text: This was not true, for these things belonged to his master; but he was a boaster.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Don't come so near me," said the garter; "I am not accustomed to it."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Affectation!" said the shirt-collar.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they were taken out of the wash-tub, starched, and hung over a chair in the sunshine, and then laid on the ironing-board.

author: HCAndersen
text: And now came the glowing iron.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Mistress widow," said the shirt-collar, "little mistress widow, I feel quite warm.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am changing, I am losing all my creases.

author: HCAndersen
text: You are burning a hole in me.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ugh!

author: HCAndersen
text: I propose to you."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You old rag," said the flat-iron, driving proudly over the collar, for she fancied herself a steam-engine, which rolls over the railway and draws carriages.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You old rag!" said she.

author: HCAndersen
text: The edges of the shirt-collar were a little frayed, so the scissors were brought to cut them smooth.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh!" exclaimed the shirt-collar, "what a first-rate dancer you would make; you can stretch out your leg so well.

author: HCAndersen
text: I never saw anything so charming; I am sure no human being could do the same."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I should think not," replied the scissors.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You ought to be a countess," said the shirt collar; "but all I possess consists of a fine gentleman, a boot-jack, and a comb.

author: HCAndersen
text: I wish I had an estate for your sake."

author: HCAndersen
text: "What! is he going to propose to me?" said the scissors, and she became so angry that she cut too sharply into the shirt collar, and it was obliged to be thrown by as useless.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I shall be obliged to propose to the hair-brush," thought the shirt collar; so he remarked one day, "It is wonderful what beautiful hair you have, my little lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: Have you never thought of being engaged?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "You might know I should think of it," answered the hair brush; "I am engaged to the boot-jack."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Engaged!" cried the shirt collar, "now there is no one left to propose to;" and then he pretended to despise all love-making.

author: HCAndersen
text: A long time passed, and the shirt collar was taken in a bag to the paper-mill.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here was a large company of rags, the fine ones lying by themselves, separated from the coarser, as it ought to be.

author: HCAndersen
text: They had all many things to relate, especially the shirt collar, who was a terrible boaster.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have had an immense number of love affairs," said the shirt collar, "no one left me any peace.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is true I was a very fine gentleman; quite stuck up.

author: HCAndersen
text: I had a boot-jack and a brush that I never used.

author: HCAndersen
text: You should have seen me then, when I was turned down.

author: HCAndersen
text: I shall never forget my first love; she was a girdle, so charming, and fine, and soft, and she threw herself into a washing tub for my sake.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was a widow too, who was warmly in love with me, but I left her alone, and she became quite black.

author: HCAndersen
text: The next was a first-rate dancer; she gave me the wound from which I still suffer, she was so passionate.

author: HCAndersen
text: Even my own hair-brush was in love with me, and lost all her hair through neglected love.

author: HCAndersen
text: Yes, I have had great experience of this kind, but my greatest grief was for the garter- the girdle I meant to say- that jumped into the wash-tub.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have a great deal on my conscience, and it is really time I should be turned into white paper."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the shirt collar came to this at last.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the rags were made into white paper, and the shirt collar became the very identical piece of paper which we now see, and on which this story is printed.

author: HCAndersen
text: It happened as a punishment to him, for having boasted so shockingly of things which were not true.

author: HCAndersen
text: And this is a warning to us, to be careful how we act, for we may some day find ourselves in the rag-bag, to be turned into white paper, on which our whole history may be written, even its most secret actions.

author: HCAndersen
text: And it would not be pleasant to have to run about the world in the form of a piece of paper, telling everything we have done, like the boasting shirt collar.
